course.title: Correct Localization - Code
course.description: This course goes over how to make tasks that feel natural, accurate, and specific to each locale. You'll learn the key elements of localization, see clear examples, and practice your localization identification skills. Let's make every task feel like it belongs right at home!

contents.body:
Hello! Welcome to this course on Correct Localization


We have noticed that many tasks contain inaccurate localized information. Each task has an assigned locale/language. According to the specified locale, all the information in a task - including the prompt, responses, and rewrites - must all contain accurately localized information.


You can find the task's assigned locale and language in the Language Assignment section right after the Prompt Guidelines. If you are unsure what the language code stands for, please look it up online:

contents.body:
üåç What is Localization?

Now that you know how to find your task's language and locale, let‚Äôs talk about localization ‚Äî and why it matters.


Definition:

Localization means adapting content so it feels natural, correct, and culturally appropriate for people in a specific region or language.

It‚Äôs more than just translation ‚Äî it‚Äôs about making content feel local.

  • Ask yourself: Would someone from this region feel like this content was made for them?


üîç What to Check When Localizing:

  • Punctuation: Symbols like commas, periods, and quotation marks vary by language.
  • Example: English uses ‚Äúquotes‚Äù, French uses ¬´ guillemets ¬ª.
  • Vocabulary: Words can mean different things in different places.
  • Example: ‚ÄúPants‚Äù in the US = trousers; in the UK = underwear.
  • Grammar: Sentence structure and word forms change across locales.
  • Example: In German, articles like ‚Äúder,‚Äù ‚Äúdie,‚Äù and ‚Äúdas‚Äù must match the noun‚Äôs gender.
  • Formatting: Pay attention to how dates, numbers, and units are written.
  • Example: 03/04/2025 = March 4 in the US, but April 3 in many other places.
  • Cultural Sensitivity: Avoid content that could be confusing or offensive.
  • Example: Some colors, symbols, or jokes don‚Äôt translate well across cultures.
  • Plus anything else that relates to making sure the response makes sense according to the task's assigned language and locale!


üîë Why It Matters

If a coder from your locale interfaces with a chatbot for a coding question, they should perfectly understand the response! Any phrasing that is not found in your locale, or inaccurate conventions (e.g. wrong punctuation, slang, wrong date formatting, etc.) would create a bad user experience. Therefore, make sure your task is fully locally accurate.


Note: You are encouraged to include localization where it feels natural and contextually appropriate. Do NOT try to force localization in prompts such that it sounds unnatural.

Natural Localization: Local currency, units, or number formatting

  • ‚ÄúYou bought snacks for ‚Ç¨4,50 and a drink for ‚Ç¨1,20...‚Äù (fr-FR)

Unnatural Localization: forced or exaggerated localization that distracts from the task

  • ‚ÄúHow many 20-inch baguettes do I need to stack on top of one another to reach the Eiffel Tower?‚Äù ‚Üí too contrived (fr-FR)

choices.answer: A. Translating words from one language to another as directly as possible.
B. Rewriting content so it works in all regions, without considering local preferences.
C. Making content look like it was written for users in a specific region, including correct language, formatting, and cultural context.
D. Using formal grammar rules to improve clarity in any language.

Common Localization Error Categories

Localization is critical to train accurate model responses for your coding and math tasks! Even small localization issues ‚Äî in grammar, formatting, or vocabulary ‚Äî can make coding and math comments, examples, or explanations feel incorrect or confusing for the target audience in the assigned locale. Here are some Do's and Don'ts when you are tasking. For more examples, please check the Instructions



‚ö†Ô∏è Function Names (e.g., main()) ‚Äî Don‚Äôt Translate

  • Function names, code syntax, keywords (if, while, print, etc.) should remain in English, as they are part of the programming language itself.
  • Translating main() to, for example, principal() (Spanish) or haupt() (German) would break the code and confuse learners or developers.

Localization Tips for Writing Prompts (Coding & Math Tasks)

When writing prompts, always tailor the context, formatting, and terminology to match the target locale. Below are common areas where localization matters:


‚úçÔ∏è Math Notation & Language

  • Use correct mathematical phrasing and notation for the locale.
  • ‚úÖ divis√© par (fr-FR)
  • ‚ùå divided by (en-US)
  • ‚úÖ Use a comma as the decimal separator where required
  • Ensure formulas are styled appropriately for local educational norms


üí± Currency and Units

  • Use region-appropriate currencies, measurements, and time formats.
  • ‚úÖ ‚Ç¨100 (es-ES)
  • ‚ùå $100 (en-US)
  • ‚úÖ centimeters (fr-FR)
  • ‚ùå inches (en-US)


üìÖ Date & Number Formats

  • Format dates and numbers to match regional conventions.
  • ‚úÖ 15/03/2025 (fr-FR, dd/mm/yyyy)
  • ‚ùå 03/15/2025 (en-US, mm/dd/yyyy)
  • ‚úÖ 3,14 (de-DE uses comma for decimal)
  • ‚ùå 3.14 (en-US uses period for decimal)


üí¨ Localized Technical Terms

  • Translate or adapt common computer science terms when a standard localized version exists.
  • ‚úÖ cadena (es-ES for "string")
  • ‚úÖ matriz (es-ES for "array")
  • ‚ùå Using untranslated "string" or "array" in instructions


‚ö†Ô∏è Function Names (e.g., main()) ‚Äî Don‚Äôt Translate

  • Function names, code syntax, keywords (if, while, print, etc.) should remain in English, as they are part of the programming language itself.
  • Translating main() to, for example, principal() (Spanish) or haupt() (German) would break the code and confuse learners or developers.

contents.body:
In this case, the contributor's assigned locale was EN_GB (English spoken in Great Britain).

Can you identify the issue in the marked comment? üëÄ




Exactly! In Great Britain, local people use "InitialiSe" not "InitialiZe", in this case the task would have a localization issue because of this detail, so try to be as careful as possible!

Now, let's run through an exercise to make sure we understand how to spot localization within a task. For each locale, make sure to do your research to ensure you have the accurate date/measurement/spelling convention.

"Un produit co√ªte $100 et mesure 12 inches de long."


What should you do?

choices.answer: A. Approve it ‚Äî dollars and inches are widely understood globally
B. Suggest changing dollars to euros, but leave inches
C. Suggest changing both $100 to 100‚ÄØ‚Ç¨ and inches to centim√®tres
D. Leave it unless there is a calculation error

contents.explanation: üìù Explanation: In fr-FR, currency should be in euros (‚Ç¨) and measurements should use the metric system (e.g., centimeters, not inches). Using U.S.-centric units breaks localization and may confuse users.

Localize like you're being audited by a family member or friend from your hometownüîé

üåüIf it wouldn‚Äôt make sense to them, tweak it until it does! And don't forget, every detail matters!


Reminder: You are encouraged to include localization where it feels natural and contextually appropriate. Do NOT try to force localization in prompts such that it sounds unnatural. However, if you DO include localized content, it MUST be accurate for the task's assigned locale. Otherwise, we will fail tasks that have inaccurate localized information.
